item.title: Distribution of brazilian population (2019)
item.description: knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, warning=F, message=FALSE) With Codes library(dplyr) library(readxl) library(tidyverse) library(janitor) Load data pop = tempfile(fileext = ".xls") dataURL <- "ftp://ftp.ibge.gov.br/Estimativas_de_Populacao/Estimativas_2019/estimativa_dou_2019.xls" download.file(dataURL, destfile=pop, mode='wb') pop <- readxl::read_excel(pop, sheet =2, skip = 1) %>% clean_names() %>% drop_na() mapa <- brmap::brmap_municipio_simples %>% clean_names() # Manipular e mesclar bases pop <- pop %>% mutate(populacao_estimada = as.numeric(populacao_estimada), municipio_cod = paste0(cod_uf, cod_munic)) %>% drop_na() dados_brasil <- mapa %>% mutate(municipio_cod = as.character(municipio_cod)) %>% inner_join(pop, by = "municipio_cod") %>% select(municipio_cod, municipio_nome, lon, lat, populacao_estimada, geometry) Plot Brazil Map #X11() ggplot(data = dados_brasil) + geom_point(aes(x=lon,y=lat,size=populacao_estimada), colour = "#cffdfd", alpha = 0.

item.title: 03.1_Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.
